results.title: Distanced creations
results.creator_credit: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Neo-Impressionists and Post-Impressionists abandoned the techniques of the Impressionists, however the diversity of styles and techniques greatly varied among the celebrated artists of the time. Colour, form and content was influenced by an awareness of non-European art such as Japanese woodcuts, and scientific theories of colour which artists Seurat and Cezanne practised with almost mathematical precision. Gaugin’s lifelong passion for the exotique, Van Gogh’s highly emotive style or Lautrec’s interest in the bohemian side of Paris represent the creative energies of the period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Painting the modern world
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Impressionists were regarded as radicals, attacked for being subversive and immoral in their subject matter and mocked for their techniques which were considered inept and unfinished. Today, they are the most popular and best loved of all schools of art. The Impressionists Courbet, Courbet, Degas, Renoir and Monet are featured in this episode.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Passionate eye
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The influence of Napoleon on French art and architecture is examined. The Emperor encouraged the classical Roman style. The age of Romanticism is studied in which the direct expression of natural feeling is extolled above the control of intellect.

results.title: The Age of reason
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The turbulence and restlessness of this period is reflected in the troubled history of France and Europe, in the first half of the 17th Century - Thirty Years War. The autocracy of Louis XIV was an example of the political response to disorder; the artistic response was a renewed emphasis on mathematical proportions and on compositions controlled by horizontals and verticals. Artists who followed after this included Poussin, Lorraine, Watteau and Jacques Louis David.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Masters of the Baroque
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Peter Paul Rubens absorbed much of the intensity of religious ecstacy and suffering portrayed by the artists working in Italy during the Counter-Reformation, excelling in the texture of flesh. Another master was Diego de Velazquez, reproducing the texture of costly materials - silks, brocades and velvet. Rembrandt’s work is examined from the perspective of the artist’s self-confidence in his ability to produce master works of art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Birth of the baroque
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The 17th century interiors of Protestant churches were filled with Baroque art. Congregations were brought to God through the richest and most dramatic use of religious imagery. The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Baroque were designed together, part of a total and individual whole. Vigorous movement embracing the entire facade is also a characteristic of Baroque architecture and Caravaggio is highlighted in this episode.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

The 17th century interiors of Protestant churches were filled with Baroque art. Congregations were brought to God through the richest and most dramatic use of religious imagery. The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Baroque were designed together, part of a total and individual whole. Vigorous movement embracing the entire facade is also a characteristic of Baroque architecture and Caravaggio is highlighted in this episode.

display_values: Crafts & Visual Arts → Art and religion

results.title: The Play of light
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The Republic of Venice had enjoyed great power and prosperity for many centuries before the Renaissance, and the city in its unique setting has long been one of the jewels of Italy. By the 16th Century, however, its political power was passing its peak. The artistic achievements express confidence and an enthusiasm for experimentation. Artists such as Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese highlight the flavour of the Venetian Renaissance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Heroic ambitions
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Leonardo, Raphael and Michelangelo were so highly regarded by their contemporaries, that they immeasurably raised the status of the artist. Popes and Princes felt honoured to be their patrons, and accorded them the respect and recognition of their equals. Earlier artists could not match the visual power and originality with which these three legendary artists were able to translate their thoughts into images.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Northern Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The love of minutely observed detail is one of the characteristics that distinguishes the art of the Northern Renaissance from that of Italy. Although the Italians too, studied the surfaces of things, their intent was to work from the inner form outwards, seeking an organising principle or harmony outlying outward appearances. It is in the work of Jan van Eyck and the master Albrecht Durer, that the style of the Northern Renaissance is best showcased.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Early Renaissance of Italy
results.creator_credit: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Covers the revival and reinterpretation of the classical tradition in the works of Florentine artists Masaccio, Donatello, and Ghiberti. Discusses how these artists exemplify the merging of Christian and humanistic values. Examines the realism of Jan van Eyck and the spiritual crisis of Northern Europe as revealed in Gruenwald’s Isenheim altarpiece. Discusses the spirit of the Renaissance as reflected in Durer’s work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
